title: Memory Leak
body:
After a double rotation of the OSMonitor Activity there are in heap memory 2 instances more of:

class com.eolwral.osmonitor.OSMonitor @ 0x12cf0000
class com.eolwral.osmonitor.ui.ProcessFragment @ 0x12d8bc00
class com.eolwral.osmonitor.ui.ConnectionFragment @ 0x12d8ec00
class com.eolwral.osmonitor.ui.MiscFragment @ 0x12d8f800
class com.eolwral.osmonitor.ui.MessageFragment @ 0x12d90800

It should not be like this because the rotations return to the same GUI state and the memory should stay in the same state as well. It could be a symptom of a bad management of the onCreate-onDestroy lifecycle. 

I have encountered this problem on an Android emulator running 7.1.1 os version.

title: Seems to work on LineageOS 14.1 (Android 7.1.2)
body:
Hi,

the README says: "Due to Android 7.0's security enhancement, OS Monitor won't work any more, I decide to move the project into manitenance mode, it won't support Android 7.0 and following version."

I decided to try it out anyway and installed version 3.5.0.6, which seems to work fine for me (needed to give it root permissions to be able to view all processes, but that's kind of expected). Is there something I'm missing, or is it maybe dependent on the device or custom firmware being used?

title: Force-close only works in landscape mode
body:
Just discovered something odd. The force close button works in landscape mode, but when I switch to portrait mode, it no longer functions. (hold on process, press "Force Close" in popup, nothing happens -- switch to landscape, and it works)

EDIT: Apparently it's that the popup's "force close" button doesn't work (in portrait or landscape), whereas the side panel's button does. Odd.

How is the popup being created? I don't see any UI controls declared with the text "Force close" other than the sidebar's/ProcessFragment's button. Is it generated based on the buttons in the sidebar?

title: Scaling CPU usage to per core
body:
With the architecture of modern smartphones, i think it would probably make more sense to show CPU usage scaled to 100% being full utilization of one core, at least as an option.

With the current system, my phone "pegs" at 16%, and I don't think it could ever exceed 50%, since the little cores aren't use st the same time as the big cores from what I understand.

title: OS Monitor causes whole system stuttering on Xperia Z3
body:
Yes, I know it sounds weird. 

I had a problem with my Z3 (stock Marshmallow) where it would freeze up for a fraction of a second every few seconds. I've tracked it down to OS Monitor: those stutters seem to happen only when it's polling the system. There's a bunch of lines like this printed to logcat when that happens, perhaps it's related:

`05-01 21:02:07.877  6699  6699 W osmcore : type=1400 audit(0.0:3470533): avc: denied { getattr } for path="/proc/1" dev="proc" ino=935969 scontext=u:r:untrusted_app:s0:c512,c768 tcontext=u:r:init:s0 tclass=dir permissive=0 ppid=1 pcomm="init" tgid=1 tgcomm="init"

title: Gear VR: "Click to start OS Monitor..."
body:
When using with the Samsung Gear VR, a black box with:

```
   OS Montior
   Click to start OS Monitor...
```

is displayed statically near the bottom (i.e. the `ui_shortcut_detail` string).

Seems to be related to the notification, but OS Monitor is the only app I have installed that appears in VR mode.  Only resolution so far seems to be exit OS Monitor before using the Gear.  Has anyone else experienced this or have a workaround?

Present on (from my testing):
- Galaxy Note 4 with Gear VR Innovator Edition
- Galaxy S7 Edge with Gear VR final

title: use resident, not virtual for memory usage
body:
Right now OSMonitor use virtual size when sorting by memory usage.

This however include various memory pages that are not in active use, or shared across multiple processed (shared libraries etc).

resident is the size the process is actively using.

title: Mac address is truncated by one character
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
On **MISC** tab/**Network**/ info about **MAC** addresesses of network interace are truncated by one character.
It's look like bug in function network::getMACInformation() in network.cc file.

> line 231: curMACLen = read(curMAC, readBuffer, 17); _// read from /sys/class/net/net_interface_name/address_
> line 232: strncpy(curMACAddr, readBuffer, 16);

Line 232 it's in my opinion not necessary, because on line 231 takes readings of mac address value and trim it to the right length. Mac Addres length is 16 chars + \0 (end string mark) = 17 chars. strncopy(curMACAddr, readBuffer, 16) cuts last char.
I think that
`line 231: curMACLen = read(curMAC, curMACAddr, 17);` 
`line 232: delete it`
or 
`line 231: curMACLen = read(curMAC, readBuffer, 17);`
`line 232: strncpy(curMACAddr, readBuffer, 17);`
should  be fine

title: Wrong filenames / path in install_binary.sh and build.sh
body:
Hi,

when running the ndk-build in the OSMonitor subdir the compiled native binaries are located in:

```
libs/armeabi/osmcore
libs/mips/osmcore
libs/x86/osmcore
libs/armeabi/osmcore_pie
libs/mips/osmcore_pie
libs/x86/osmcore_pie
```

https://github.com/eolwral/OSMonitor/blob/master/build.sh uses the correct subdir but the wrong filenames for the build binaries.

https://github.com/eolwral/OSMonitor/blob/master/OSMonitor/jni/install_binary.sh uses the correct filenames but the wrong path (expecting the binaries are located in the jni folder.

title: Frequency Min > Frequency Max
body:
Hello!

In OS Monitor 3.3.0.5, there is a strange frequency bounds behavior. If I select any CPU frequency from Frequency Min menu, it instantly becomes back the maximum possible CPU frequency (1209000 on my chipset). But Frequency Max can be changed to each possible value (497250, 754000, 988000, 1209000) and remains until I leave CPU settings menu.

But when I enter CPU settings menu again, Min/Max frequencies are always the same, equal to max chipset frequency (1209000). Only governor setting persists.

I have Zopo ZP980/C2 (MT6589 chipset), Android 4.2.1 (the firmware from 18.08.2014).

Is such behavior normal for my chipset/OS, or there is a bug in OS Monitor?

Regards,
Eugene

title: Use native code binaries from libs/ and not from assets/
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body: Doing the latter prevents Android from knowing what ABIs does a built APK support. It also overcomplicates the build process when it needn't be. You can access stuff from libs/<arch>/ in a similar way to how you access assets, if that's what keeps you from using the regular ndk-build output directory.

title: Sum of Memory usage of processes
label: [Label(name="question")]
body:
Hi,

my xperia MK16i is low of memory (it has only 512MB!) an I want to find out, what processes are consuming the memory.

OSMonitor seems the right tool for this!

I did the following:
-  In the process list I sort after memory usage
- I made screenshots of this list and typed each amount in Excel
- I added each amount

The sum is much higher as "Memory Total" in the footer of the list: 529,3 MB (manual sum) to 356,4 MB (OSMonitor sum). How can this be?

How do you build the sum?

I attach you the screenshots and a Excel file screenshot to make it possible for you to reconstruct what I mean.

What type of memory does OSMonitor show in this list?

Can this list help me me at all to show, from what App the memory is assumted?

Best regards,

Onurbi

title: Adding an option to display CPU time
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Hi, OSMonitor is a great app! Very useful and well-designed.

I think it's missing an important feature, the ability to display the total CPU time consumed by each process. 

Current CPU usage is useful to determine if an app is misbehaving, but won't help much to find if an application is a CPU hog only when it's being used by the user. For example, a recent weather app I installed eats massive amounts of CPU time when being used, but stays idle when it's not. So it would display "0%" CPU usage on OSMonitor and it was harder to detect that there was a problem with it.

Just a thought :)

title: WHOIS Map can't load

title: Can't report tun0 traffic
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body: tun0 is an interface related to a VPN IPsec

title: Build problem: missing symbols
body:
For 3.0.6.4:
`compile:
    [javac] Compiling 70 source files to /home/gerry/fdroiddata/build/com.eolwral.osmonitor/OSMonitor/bin/classes
    [javac] /home/gerry/fdroiddata/build/com.eolwral.osmonitor/OSMonitor/src/com/eolwral/osmonitor/OSMonitorService.java:122: error: cannot find symbol
    [javac]         Notification osNotification = nBuilder.build();
    [javac]                                               ^
    [javac]   symbol:   method build()
    [javac]   location: variable nBuilder of type Builder
    [javac] /home/gerry/fdroiddata/build/com.eolwral.osmonitor/OSMonitor/src/com/eolwral/osmonitor/OSMonitorService.java:297: error: cannot find symbol
    [javac]         nBuilder.setStyle(new NotificationCompat.BigTextStyle().bigText(
    [javac]                                                 ^
    [javac]   symbol:   class BigTextStyle
    [javac]   location: class NotificationCompat
    [javac] /home/gerry/fdroiddata/build/com.eolwral.osmonitor/OSMonitor/src/com/eolwral/osmonitor/OSMonitorService.java:317: error: cannot find symbol
    [javac]         nManager.notify(NOTIFYID, nBuilder.build());
    [javac]                                           ^
    [javac]   symbol:   method build()
    [javac]   location: variable nBuilder of type Builder
    [javac] 3 errors
==== stdout end ====
==== stderr begin ====
BUILD FAILED`

Also the latin1 encoding was used to avoid unmappable character warnings and had to do 
`+sed -i 's/osinfo/osInfo/g' jni/include/core/os.h && \
+sed -i 's/ConnectionInfo.pb.h/connectionInfo.pb.h/g' \`

title: Incorrect IPv6 addresses are shown on MISC>Network>Interfaces
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
IPv6 addresses are shown correctly on CONNECTION page, but not on MISC page.
The loopback, which I believe it should be `::1/128`, is shown as `::1.0.0.0/128`.
My wlan0, say it's `123:4567:890A:BCDE:FGHI:JKLM:NOPQ:RSTU/64`, is shown as `6745:2301:DEBC:A89:LMJK:HIFG:TURS:PQNO/64`.

title: quadcore: os monitor only displays three cores
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body: I have an Galaxy S 3 LTE with a quadcore cpu. In "MISC" I only see three cores (core 0, 1 and 2; two of them "online", one "offline") instead of four.

title: >100% CPU Usage reported on Nexus S
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
After the recent update that overhauled the UI (I think two updates ago), I sometimes observe the total "CPU Usage" (reported in the Process tab) exceed 100%. Is this expected? I didn't observe this behavior previously. I'm using a 3G Nexus S with Android 4.1.2.

By the way, thanks for this app -- it's terrific in general.
